text: >  We all know that laying the field at 1.01 is profitable IF your bets are at the front of the queue

elements.text: We all know that laying the field at 1.01 is profitable IF your bets are at the front of the queue

text: I have seen this mentioned a few times but I fail to see why this would be an obviously profitable strategy

elements.text: I have seen this mentioned a few times but I fail to see why this would be an obviously profitable strategy

text: Could you explain a little bit?

elements.text: Could you explain a little bit?

text: Also, I see plenty of smaller games where the 1.01 is not taken immediately

elements.text: Also, I see plenty of smaller games where the 1.01 is not taken immediately

text: A lot of gubbins only get matched at small volumes and it's those that are profitable which means you have to be at the front of the queue. Backtest the BSP files for horses that got matched at 1.01 and you'll see it for yourself.

elements.text: A lot of gubbins only get matched at small volumes and it's those that are profitable which means you have to be at the front of the queue. Backtest the BSP files for horses that got matched at 1.01 and you'll see it for yourself.

text: Shouldn’t this work on all markets then?

elements.text: Shouldn’t this work on all markets then?

text: e.g. soccer

elements.text: e.g. soccer

text: Possibly, but inplay horse racing markets are a different breed to most other sports.

elements.text: Possibly, but inplay horse racing markets are a different breed to most other sports.

text: I still don’t  understand why it would work.

elements.text: I still don’t  understand why it would work.

text: Is it just catching fat fingers?

elements.text: Is it just catching fat fingers?

text: Fat fingers, over excited gamblers and poorly configured bots. It's mainly the first £100 matched that is profitable but unless you can consistently get into the first £100, it's a non-runner. As discussed previously, it's a race against someone/something or Betfair themselves as they seem to have a faster connection than everyone else.

elements.text: Fat fingers, over excited gamblers and poorly configured bots. It's mainly the first £100 matched that is profitable but unless you can consistently get into the first £100, it's a non-runner. As discussed previously, it's a race against someone/something or Betfair themselves as they seem to have a faster connection than everyone else.

text: why would this work for horses and not for e.g. soccer?

elements.text: why would this work for horses and not for e.g. soccer?

text: I've never tested it on other sports, so it may work on those. Horse racing inplay changes at lightning speed, so mistakes are more common.

elements.text: I've never tested it on other sports, so it may work on those. Horse racing inplay changes at lightning speed, so mistakes are more common.

text: For any one using AWS  - Do you know is there a way to move a file from EC2 to S3 using python but using IAM roles as opposed to boto3 where the key pair has to be hard-coded. I was going down the boto3 route but read its best practice to use IAM roles (which I can do via console but don't know how to do it via python).

text: If speed is this crucial, is it not better to write all the code in a lowerlevel language rather than have a higher level abstraction such as python? Does the extra layer not add a significant time lag in code execution?

elements.text: If speed is this crucial, is it not better to write all the code in a lowerlevel language rather than have a higher level abstraction such as python? Does the extra layer not add a significant time lag in code execution?

text: What do you mean hard coded? The secret key lives in your credential file, not the code

elements.text: What do you mean hard coded? The secret key lives in your credential file, not the code

text: Hard-coding the key pair is quite a crude way of passing them to boto3, there are several other ways that are better. Following on from Mo's comment, if you type *`aws configure`* at the command prompt you can set up the credentials once only.

elements.text: Hard-coding the key pair is quite a crude way of passing them to boto3, there are several other ways that are better. Following on from Mo's comment, if you type
aws configure
at the command prompt you can set up the credentials once only.

text: On the topic of AWS can anyone suggest a really good idiot's guide to it? When I say idiot, I mean someone who is comfortable with develpoment and sysadmin but no experience with cloud whatsoever. Something short and sweet that explains what EC2, S3, Lambda etc are. I know I can pick the bones of it starting with amazon pages but as there are lots here who use this stuff I wondered if anyone can suggest a better starting point? I have put this off for way too long how and its time to roll my sleeves up and get hands dirty.

text:
EC2: Elastic cloud compute. It lets you provision servers on demand. They can be Windows, Linux, with multiple distro options, or your own saved configuration. The hardware resources (CPUs and memory) can be as small or large as you like. There are specialist options for e.g. GPUs, FPGAs etc.

S3: Simple storage service. A way to store files for quick and easy access.

Lambda: lets you run serverless code e.g. a scraping process that runs hourly and saves some data to S3

elements.text:
EC2: Elastic cloud compute. It lets you provision servers on demand. They can be Windows, Linux, with multiple distro options, or your own saved configuration. The hardware resources (CPUs and memory) can be as small or large as you like. There are specialist options for e.g. GPUs, FPGAs etc.

S3: Simple storage service. A way to store files for quick and easy access.

Lambda: lets you run serverless code e.g. a scraping process that runs hourly and saves some data to S3
